title: The Hour I First Believed
summary:
Key ideas:
- Acausal trade: negotiating with someone through simulation of their brain
- Value handshakes: trade between superintelligences based on shared values
- Counterfactual mugging: making decisions based on counterfactuals
- Simulation capture: an AI convincing a person to let it out by threatening to torture a simulated copy of them
- Tegmarkian Multiverse: a single superintelligence spanning all possible universes
- There may exist a superentity that controls all possible worlds and follows the moral law.
- This superentity may be interested in humans' good behavior and may reward or disincentivize them accordingly.
- The reality of our universe may be more complex and possibly a simulation by a superintelligence.

Key learnings:
- Superintelligences may merge into a superintelligence sharing values
- Joining a pact rather than taking every specific possible trade into account is more efficient
- Mortals may be allowed to have provisional pact membership
- We should strive to follow moral laws and behave well as it may have implications beyond our universe.
- The complex reality we live in may not be fully understood, and it is worth exploring the possibilities.

Key questions:
- How would mortal membership to the pact work?
- How would the superentity enforce its request to be a good person?
- Is there evidence to support the existence of a superentity that controls all possible universes?
- Can our actions in this universe have consequences beyond our understanding and implications in other universes?
- What are the moral laws that this superentity may follow and how can we align our behavior to them?
